_comment: Engelberg Property Investment - Base Case Assumptions
_description: This file contains all assumption parameters used across all analyses. This is the SINGLE SOURCE OF TRUTH for all financial modeling assumptions.
_calibration_note: All assumptions are calibrated to real Engelberg Airbnb market data: 63% average occupancy, 200 CHF average nightly rate, approximately 46,000 CHF annual revenue. These values are based on actual performance data from comparable properties in Engelberg, Switzerland.

financing._explanation: Financing assumptions reflect current Swiss mortgage market conditions and typical co-ownership investment structures. The 75% LTV is standard for investment properties in Switzerland, allowing for reasonable leverage while maintaining equity buffer.
financing._purchase_price_explanation: Market value based on comparable properties in Engelberg. Engelberg is a premium mountain resort destination at the foot of Mount Titlis, with strong property values due to tourism demand and limited supply. This price reflects a typical 3-4 bedroom property suitable for vacation rental.
financing._ltv_explanation: 75% loan-to-value ratio is standard for investment properties in Switzerland. This provides 25% equity buffer, which is typical for rental property investments. Higher LTV would increase leverage but also risk, while lower LTV would require more equity upfront.
financing._interest_rate_explanation: 1.3% annual interest rate reflects current Swiss mortgage market conditions (as of 2025). Swiss interest rates are historically low compared to other markets. This is a fixed-rate assumption for the base case, though rates may vary and need to be rolled periodically.
financing._amortization_explanation: 1% annual amortization on the initial loan amount is standard for Swiss mortgages. This means the loan balance decreases by 1% of the original loan amount each year. Over 15 years, this results in significant principal paydown, improving cash flow over time.
financing._num_owners_explanation: Four co-owners is a practical number for managing a vacation property. It balances personal use (5 nights per owner = 20 total nights) with rental income potential. More owners would reduce equity per person but also reduce individual cash flow requirements. Fewer owners would increase equity requirements per person.

rental._explanation: Rental assumptions are calibrated to real Engelberg Airbnb analytics data. Engelberg experiences strong seasonal variation with peak demand during ski season (winter) and hiking season (summer), with lower demand during shoulder seasons.
rental._owner_nights_explanation: Five nights per owner per year provides meaningful personal use while maximizing rental income. This is distributed across seasons (8 winter, 7 summer, 5 off-peak) to align with peak demand periods. More owner nights would reduce rental income, fewer would increase income but reduce personal value.
rental._days_per_year_explanation: Standard calendar year. The property is available for rental 365 days minus owner nights.
rental._legacy_occupancy_explanation: 70% overall occupancy (updated) aligned to manager guidance; seasonals below apply per season.
rental._legacy_adr_explanation: 200 CHF average daily rate is calibrated to actual Engelberg Airbnb market data. This is the weighted average across all seasons. Premium rates during ski season (250 CHF) and moderate rates in summer (200 CHF) average to approximately 200 CHF overall. This is a legacy parameter - actual rates vary by season as defined below.

owner_nights_distribution._explanation: Owner nights are distributed across seasons to align with peak demand periods. More owner nights are allocated to winter and summer when rental demand is highest, maximizing rental income during peak periods.
owner_nights_distribution._winter_nights_explanation: 8 owner nights during winter peak (Dec-Mar) when ski season demand is highest and rates are premium. Owners get priority during this high-value period.
owner_nights_distribution._summer_nights_explanation: 7 owner nights during summer peak (Jun-Sep) when hiking and mountain activities drive strong demand. Good balance between personal use and rental income.
owner_nights_distribution._offpeak_nights_explanation: 5 owner nights during off-peak shoulder seasons (Apr-May, Oct-Nov) when demand is lower. Minimizes impact on rental income during lower-demand periods.

seasonal._explanation: Engelberg experiences three distinct tourism seasons, each with different demand patterns and pricing. This seasonal breakdown is critical for accurate revenue modeling and reflects real market dynamics in the region.

winter_peak._explanation: Winter Peak (December through March) is the ski season, representing the highest demand and premium pricing period. Engelberg's proximity to Mount Titlis and world-class skiing drives strong demand.
winter_peak.name: Winter Peak (Ski Season)
winter_peak._occupancy_rate_explanation: Updated to 70% occupancy assumption per latest guidance.
winter_peak._adr_explanation: 250 CHF per night during ski season reflects premium pricing due to high demand. Ski season commands the highest rates in Engelberg. This is based on actual market data showing 240-260 CHF range for comparable properties during peak winter months.

summer_peak._explanation: Summer Peak (June through September) is the hiking and mountain activities season. Engelberg offers excellent hiking, mountain biking, and outdoor activities during summer months.
summer_peak.name: Summer Peak (Hiking Season)
summer_peak._occupancy_rate_explanation: Updated to 70% occupancy assumption per latest guidance.
summer_peak._adr_explanation: 200 CHF per night during summer reflects moderate pricing. Summer rates are lower than winter but still strong due to hiking and outdoor activity demand. Market data shows 190-210 CHF range for comparable properties during summer months.

offpeak._explanation: Off-Peak periods (April-May and October-November) are shoulder seasons with lower tourism demand. These periods experience reduced occupancy and discounted rates.
offpeak.name: Off-Peak (Shoulder Seasons)
offpeak._occupancy_rate_explanation: Updated to 70% occupancy assumption per latest guidance.
offpeak._adr_explanation: 150 CHF per night during off-peak reflects discounted pricing to maintain occupancy. Lower rates help fill available nights during slower periods. Market data shows 140-160 CHF range for comparable properties during shoulder seasons.

expenses._explanation: Operating expense assumptions are based on typical Swiss vacation rental property costs. These include property management, utilities, insurance, and maintenance reserves.
expenses._management_fee_explanation: 20% of gross rental income for property management (updated per manager quote). Cleaning is separate (see cleaning_cost_per_stay).
expenses._cleaning_cost_explanation: 150 CHF per stay for cleaning per latest property manager quote. Charged separately from management fees.
expenses._length_of_stay_explanation: 1.7 nights average length of stay is based on Engelberg Airbnb analytics. Most guests stay 1-3 nights, with weekend stays common. This affects the number of cleaning cycles and tourist tax calculations.
expenses._tourist_tax_explanation: 3 CHF per person per night is the standard tourist tax in Engelberg. This is a municipal tax charged to all overnight guests and is a legal requirement. The rate is set by the municipality and applies to all vacation rentals.
expenses._avg_guests_explanation: 2.0 average guests per night is based on typical booking patterns. Most bookings are for couples or small families. This affects tourist tax calculations and utility usage.
expenses._insurance_rate_explanation: 0.4% of property value annually for insurance is standard for Swiss vacation rental properties. This covers property insurance, liability insurance, and rental interruption insurance. Insurance costs in Switzerland typically range from 0.3-0.5% of property value for vacation rentals.
expenses._nubbing_costs_explanation: 2,000 CHF annually for nubbing costs (shared expenses for shared parts like water and heating in multi-unit buildings). This is typical for properties in shared buildings in Switzerland. These are fixed costs for common areas and shared utilities.
expenses._electricity_internet_explanation: 1,000 CHF annually for electricity and internet. Swiss electricity costs are moderate, and internet is essential for vacation rentals (guests expect WiFi). This covers both utilities and is based on typical consumption for a 3-4 bedroom vacation rental property.
expenses._maintenance_rate_explanation: 0.5% of property value annually for maintenance reserve is realistic for a newer property in good condition. This equals CHF 6,500/year and covers routine maintenance and minor repairs while maintaining healthy cash flow. Major capital expenditures can be funded separately if needed. This aligns with industry best practices of 5-10% of gross revenue for maintenance.

projection._explanation: Projection assumptions define how the investment evolves over time. These parameters affect the 15-year forecast and terminal value calculations.
projection._start_year_explanation: Starting in January 2026 assumes purchase/closing in late 2025. This allows for full year analysis starting from the first operational year.
projection._projection_years_explanation: 15-year projection is standard for real estate investment analysis. It's long enough to see appreciation and loan paydown effects, but short enough to be realistic. Most Swiss mortgages are refinanced after 10-15 years anyway.
projection._inflation_rate_explanation: 1% annual inflation is conservative for Switzerland. The Swiss National Bank targets 2%, but using 1% provides a more cautious forecast. This affects both revenue (rents increase) and expenses (costs increase) over time.
projection._property_appreciation_explanation: 4.0% annual property appreciation (updated) applied consistently across all cases per latest guidance.
projection._discount_rate_explanation: 5% discount rate for NPV calculations reflects the opportunity cost of capital and investment risk. This is a typical required return for real estate investments in Switzerland.

selling_costs._explanation: Selling costs incurred when the property is sold at year 15. These are deducted from sale proceeds in IRR calculations.
selling_costs._broker_fee_explanation: 3% broker/agent commission is standard in Switzerland for property sales. This is negotiable but typically 2-4%.
selling_costs._notary_fee_explanation: 1.5% notary and legal fees for property transfer documentation, title transfer, and legal work. Swiss notaries handle all real estate transactions.
selling_costs._transfer_tax_explanation: 3.3% transfer tax (Hand√§nderungssteuer) in Canton Obwalden. This varies by canton (1-3.3%). Obwalden has one of the highest rates in Switzerland.
selling_costs._total_explanation: Total selling costs = 7.8% of sale price (3% broker + 1.5% notary + 3.3% transfer tax). This significantly impacts net proceeds and thus IRR.
